content.title: Unlocking Energy Access with Digital Tools, Data and AI
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 5

content.text: Lesson 5 Overview

Expanding energy access to underserved communities requires smarter planning, better targeting, and innovative delivery models. This lesson explores how data, digital technologies, and artificial intelligence (AI) are transforming the way energy systems are designed, managed, and financed in low- and middle-income countries. You’ll learn how geospatial data and platforms like the Global Electrification Platform and Energy Access Explorer enable planners to identify high-need areas and select the most cost-effective solutions. The lesson also highlights the role of AI in improving reliability and efficiency—through smarter demand forecasting, microgrid optimization, and fault detection—especially in remote or fragile contexts. Finally, it examines how mobile money and peer-to-peer energy trading are expanding affordability and inclusion, empowering users to pay flexibly and participate directly in local energy markets. Together, these tools are helping close the energy access gap while supporting more equitable and sustainable energy systems.

content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: community empowerment
concepts.body: Community empowerment is the process of enabling individuals and groups within a community to gain control over their lives, make decisions, and take action to improve their social, economic, and environmental conditions.

concepts.title: multi-stakeholder partnership
concepts.body: A multi-stakeholder partnership is a collaborative arrangement involving various parties, such as governments, businesses, non-profits, and communities, working together to achieve common goals, often related to sustainable development or social impact.

concepts.title: participatory diagnosis, design, monitoring, and evaluation
concepts.body: A collaborative approach that involves stakeholders in the processes of diagnosing issues, designing solutions, monitoring progress, and evaluating outcomes to ensure that their perspectives and needs are integrated.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 5 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Data-Driven Energy Planning to Map Energy Access

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Data is at the heart of modern energy planning as it allows decision-makers to allocate resources effectively, identify the most appropriate and cost-effective places to develop energy projects, and monitor progress toward universal access. To achieve universal access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy by 2030 , it is crucial to use all effective tools available to accelerate infrastructure development, including data-driven strategies that prioritize the most underserved communities and optimize the use of public and private resources. As electrification efforts thrive to reach those who need it the most — remote and marginalized populations, planning based on accurate, detailed, and timely data becomes essential.
Limitations of Traditional Planning Approaches and the role of Geospatial Data

Historically, energy access planning has relied on national-level statistics, infrastructure maps, and household surveys, not necessarily including spatial resolution and timely updates. These methods frequently overlook informal settlements, rural populations who may be dispersed across a territory, and seasonal energy demand fluctuations. Without detailed and reliable data, energy planners risk misallocating investments or extending grids into areas where decentralized solutions such as solar mini-grids or standalone systems would be more cost-effective and reliable. Geospatial data, referring to location-based information that is used to more effectively map, analyze, and plan energy access and distribution solutions can bring a new dimension to energy planning by allowing for spatial analysis of people’s living location, their proximity to existing grids, solar radiation levels, road access, and more. By layering these variables in a geographic information system (GIS), planners can create detailed energy access maps that identify which communities lack electricity, and what is the most appropriate technology and delivery model for each context. This allows for decisionmakers and investors to compare different energy solutions such as grid extension, mini-grids, or standalone solutions.
Tools and Platforms for Geospatial Energy Planning

There exist several open-access tools that support governments, utilities, and investors in planning energy access using geospatial data. Among the most widely used are the Global Electrification Platform (GEP) developed by the World Bank’s Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP), and the Energy Access Explorer (EAE) from the World Resources Institute. These platforms combine population data, infrastructure data, and economic modeling to recommend least-cost electrification pathways.

Geospatial tools enable the possibility to identify underserved areas with high energy needs that can be invisible in traditional datasets. For example, the Energy Access Explorer (EAE) platform uses data layers like health facility locations ( as displayed in the map) , productive use potential, night-time light intensity, and socioeconomic factors to identify where investments for energy access can have the biggest impact. This is particularly relevant in fragile contexts or regions with informal urbanization where official grid maps may be outdated or incomplete. Geospatial planning tools can also incorporate predictive modeling, which are algorithms and simulations to forecast future energy demand, to determine the most cost-effective technology for expanding electricity access. For example, the Global Electrification Platform (GEP) uses simulations of multiple scenarios to compare the costs of grid extension versus mini-grid or standalone solar systems under different demand assumptions. This allows policymakers to direct investments more efficiently, ensuring limited public funds are used where they have the highest return in terms of access per dollar spent. According to ESMAP, least-cost geospatial modeling in Nigeria determines that mini-grids were the most cost-effective option to electrify 30 million people, and standalone solar can serve another 20 million (ESMAP., 2022).
Energy Access Explorer (EAE)

The EAE is an open-access, interactive geospatial planning platform developed by WRI in partnership with national and local stakeholders. It was created in response to the lack of access to reliable data and analytical tools necessary for informed energy access planning, particularly among governments, local utilities, NGOs, and small energy companies. The EAE supports technology planning but also integrates social and economic data into its spatial analysis. It is deployed in Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, and India, and enables planners to identify where energy access can maximize impact, for instance, by targeting health clinics, schools, and small businesses.

The map above presents a geospatial output from the Energy Access Explorer , visualizing areas in Ethiopia that meet two criteria: proximity within 200 km of agricultural markets and distance of over 20 km from existing distribution lines. These filters were applied to show the EAE’s ability to determine potential for energy access expansion. The map highlights relatively underserved regions where electrification efforts, like mini-grids or standalone systems, could meet the needs of unelectrified communities and promote productive use of energy in agricultural value chains. This type of analysis helps planners optimize investment locations based on overlapping socio-economic and infrastructure factors Source: Energy Access Explorer: An open access tool to enable data-driven energy planning, WRI, 2024

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 5 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: AI-Powered Energy Management and Optimization for Energy Access

content.text: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is emerging as a powerful tool to address some of the biggest challenges in expanding energy access, especially in remote and underserved regions. In many developing countries, power systems face high variability in demand, limited grid capacity, and frequent outages. AI offers innovative solutions that can optimize the way energy is generated, distributed, and consumed, thus making systems more efficient, reliable, and responsive to the needs of local communities. This section explores how AI can support energy access by improving demand forecasting, optimizing microgrid operations, enhancing system reliability, and enabling smarter planning and financial models. From intelligent Energy Management Systems (EMS) to adaptive tariff structures and automated fault detection, AI technologies can help build energy systems that are smarter, but also more inclusive and resilient.
Smarter Grids through AI-Based Demand Forecasting

Artificial Intelligence (AI) has the potential to transform the way electricity demand is managed for both grid-connected and off-grid systems. In developing countries, where power systems often encounter obstacles like irregular demand, limited capacity, and high outage rates, AI models such as can help utilities anticipate consumption patterns and adapt electricity supply accordingly. These models analyze historical and real-time data to predict peak loads —referring to the highest amount of electricity demand on a system at a given time — and adjust power supply accordingly, thus reducing blackouts and improving energy efficiency.
Optimizing Microgrid Operations with AI-Enhanced EMS

Energy Management Systems (EMS) are crucial for the effectiveness of decentralized energy systems, particularly microgrids. AI-enhanced EMS can coordinate solar panels, batteries, diesel generators, and loads to balance supply and demand in real-time. Algorithms like fuzzy logic—which mimics human reasoning by controlling uncertainty— allow these systems to adapt dynamically. These solutions are especially effective in remote areas, where traditional grid infrastructure is unreliable or nonexistent.
Boosting Reliability through AI-Driven Monitoring and Fault Detection

AI can also improve the reliability and resilience of energy systems through continuous monitoring and early fault detection. Using models such as decision trees and hybrid AI systems, faults can be detected in real time and classified for corrective action. AI-enabled microgrids may help ensure more consistent energy access in critical sectors, helping prevent power outages in health facilities for instance.
Designing Efficient Microgrids with AI Algorithms

Microgrid planning in rural and low-income areas requires balancing cost, reliability, and future growth. Advanced AI techniques can evaluate thousands of configuration scenarios quickly and simulate how systems respond under different load conditions, weather patterns, and economic assumptions. This can allow planners to design microgrids that are resilient, scalable, and affordable.
Enhancing Affordability and Productive Use

AI can also help make decentralized energy more financially sustainable. Smart tariff systems can be designed using real-time usage data, leading to flexible billing structures that match household income patterns. AI can also schedule productive-use appliances (like irrigation pumps or grinders) during low-demand periods, which can improve the overall system efficiency. This approach has the potential to increase microgrid revenue while enhancing affordability for users.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 5 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Digital tools for Inclusion and affordability in Energy Access

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Digital innovation is playing an important role in expanding access to clean and affordable energy, especially in underserved and off-grid communities. From mobile payment platforms that unlock access to energy financing, to blockchain-enabled peer-to-peer energy trading systems, digital technologies are reshaping how energy is distributed, and paid for, with the potential of making energy systems more inclusive and responsive to local needs. This section explores how digital tools can improve the inclusivity and affordability of energy access. It explores peer-to-peer energy trading that use blockchain and IoT, mobile money solutions that support pay-as-you-go solar access, and presents the link between energy and connectivity, showing how digital tools can accelerate progress toward universal energy access.
Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading

Peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading is a decentralized model that enables energy consumers, often called "prosumers" (the contraction of producers and consumers), to sell excess energy, usually from solar panels, to their neighbors or to the local grid. This paradigm shift in energy management can support greater energy access by empowering local communities to become active participants in energy markets, especially in rural and underserved areas where traditional grid infrastructure is limited or unreliable.
Technological Enablers: Blockchain and IoT

Two main technologies have made P2P trading possible: blockchain and the Internet of Things (IoT). Blockchain ensures transparency, trust, and reliable transaction records through smart contracts, that removes the need for intermediaries. At the same time, IoT devices allow for real-time energy data monitoring, linking prosumers and consumers through smart meters and gateways that track production and consumption at a granular level. When combined, these technologies can create secure, autonomous energy markets that enable local energy trading, even in areas with minimal internet connectivity. Blockchain’s distributed ledger, which is a decentralized system where transactions are recorded across multiple nodes, ensures transparency and trust among participants without the need for central authority. This ledger also enables tokenized payments, where units of energy can be represented as digital tokens exchanged securely between users, allowing fast, low-cost, and verifiable peer-to-peer energy settlements.
Applications and Benefits

P2P energy trading has the potential to improve energy affordability and reliability in developing countries by allowing households with surplus solar energy to sell to neighbors, thus reducing dependency on centralized suppliers and reducing energy costs through local supply chains. Farmers in rural communities, for instance, can meet their energy needs via solar and trade excess power to generate additional income. Pilot projects like those in Bangladesh and Kenya are already exploring these models to enhance rural electrification and economic inclusion .
Barriers and Challenges

Despite the promises, P2P energy trading faces regulatory, technical, and social challenges. Many developing countries lack a clear legal framework to support decentralized energy markets. Technical issues such as the cost of smart meters, data security, and platform reliability also pose challenges. Social acceptance is another key factor as local communities may not trust the technology or be willing to trade electricity with neighbors. Policy support, awareness campaigns, and low-cost platforms are necessary to ensure successful adoption.
Mobile Money and Fintech Solutions: Expanding Financial Access for Off-Grid Households

In many developing regions, particularly sub-Saharan Africa, traditional banking infrastructure remains limited, leaving vast segments of the population without access to essential financial services. As of 2021, around 1.4 billion adults globally were unbanked, including approximately 360 million in Sub-Saharan Africa, representing about 45% of the region’s population (Demirgüç-Kunt et al., 2022). Mobile money platforms represent potential solutions to bridge this gap, and allow off-grid households to access, afford, and manage renewable energy solutions. Mobile money services, such as Kenya's M-Pesa, have disrupted mobile money platforms and contributed tofinancial inclusion by allowing users to perform transactions via mobile phones without the need for a traditional bank account. M-PESA, launched by Safaricom in Kenya in 2007, is a mobile-based electronic payment and money transfer system. By 2010, it had reached over 9 million users, around 40% of Kenya's adult population at the time, and facilitated over $320 million in monthly person-to-person transfers. (Mas & Radcliffe., 2010). The platform enables users, even in rural and underserved areas, to deposit, withdraw, and transfer money using simple mobile phones through a vast network of over 16,900 retail agents. M-PESA may have contributed to making energy access more affordable and inclusive by allowing customers to pay energy bills, including electricity, digitally and securely. For example, Kenya's main utility company reported that around 20% of its customers paid their bills through M-PESA, which shows how mobile money can bridge financial gaps and improve access to essential energy services . In combination with the accelerated adoption of mobile payment, pay-as-you-go solar energy models, where customers make incremental payments for solar home systems can also contribute to making energy more accessible. This model allows low-income households to paying small, manageable amounts that align with their cash flow. This flexibility can improve affordability and empower previously underserved communities to access clean, reliable electricity for the first time.
Bridging the Digital Divide: Enhancing Connectivity for Underserved Communities

The digital divide refers to the disparity between individuals who have access to modern information and communication technologies (ICT) and those who do not. This gap is particularly evident between the Global North and the Global South, where limited internet access in developing countries hampers educational opportunities, economic development, and access to essential services. Globally, as of 2022, approximately 2.7 billion people—representing one-third of the world's population—remain offline, with the majority residing in developing nations (UN., 2023). In low-income countries, internet usage is significantly lower compared to high-income countries, where over 90% of the population is online. For example, in the least developed countries, only about 36% of the population uses the internet, compared to a global average of 66%. This lack of connectivity limits access to telemedicine, online education, and remote work opportunities, which also heightens existing socioeconomic inequalities. Energy access is a fundamental enabler of digital connectivity. Without reliable electricity, operating the infrastructure required for internet services like cell towers, routers, and data centers is challenging. At the same time, digital technologies can improve energy accessibility. Leveraging mobile technology for energy services, such as mobile money platforms for pay-as-you-go solar systems, has enabled millions to afford and manage renewable energy solutions. Addressing the intertwined challenges of energy poverty and the digital divide requires coordinated strategies. Investments in renewable energy infrastructure can power digital expansion, while digital tools can optimize energy distribution and consumption. Addressing both issues jointly can help foster inclusive growth and ensure that underserved communities benefit from modern technologies.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Traditional planning methods often overlook remote and underserved communities, but geospatial platforms like the Global Electrification Platform and Energy Access Explorer use layered spatial data to pinpoint energy needs and recommend least-cost solutions. These tools enable governments and investors to prioritize investments, compare delivery models, and maximize the impact of limited resources.

From forecasting energy demand to managing microgrid operations and detecting faults in real time, AI enables smarter, more resilient, and adaptive energy infrastructure, particularly in remote and resource-constrained areas. AI also supports affordability and productive use by enabling dynamic pricing, efficient load scheduling, and better system design based on real-world data.

Technologies such as blockchain, IoT, and mobile platforms are enabling new ways for users to pay for energy, share electricity, and access energy services without traditional banking or centralized grid infrastructure. These digital tools not only lower financial barriers but also empower users to participate in decentralized, community-driven energy markets.
